Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: New models and numerical methods for flexible wings, fins, and membranes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goals of this project are to create analytical and computational tools, coupled with experiments, to investigate biological propulsion in fluids at intermediate scales. These problems typically involve the movement of a flexible appendage in a fluid where both inertia and viscosity are important. The fundamental computational challenge associated with these problems is the accurate and efficient simulation of the moving, flexible structure in the surrounding fluid. One aim is to extend numerical methods for Stokes flow to Reynolds numbers on the order of 1 to 10. These methods will then be applied to aerodynamics problems involving flow through bristled wings. Another aim is to incorporate viscous effects into vortex sheet methods, in order to more accurately simulate flows over a wider range of scales. These tools will then be used to understand the importance of active control of fish fin rays and other instances of fluid interactions with organisms. Finally, this work will allow for comparisons of propulsion mechanisms and numerical methods across a wide range of Reynolds numbers.

The numerical methods and models developed in this research project can be applied to numerous and diverse biological fluid-structure interactions problems. Some examples beyond those specific to the proposal include the pumping of blood by the heart, the flow of air in the lungs, drag reduction in flexible materials such as leaves and sessile organisms, and the dispersal of seeds in air and larvae in water. The broader impacts of this work include the improved understanding of propulsion mechanics that can be used for the design of micro air and water vehicles; the development of computational tools which are useful to study optimization questions in biology; rich examples of nonlinear dynamics for physics; research mentoring to undergraduates in experimental and modeling work and graduate students in computational and modeling research. The outreach component will help more students achieve autonomy in research and critical thinking through independent research projects. This project also addresses one of the seven questions posed by the National Academy of Sciences on the role of theory in advancing 21st century biology: ``what are the engineering principles of life?''

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this work was to develop new models and numerical methods for fluid-structure interaction problems related to biological locomotion. We studied five main systems: fish fin rays, vortex-body interactions, robotic foils, jellyfish swimming, and snake crawling.

Our first project was to understand the mechanics of the fish fin ray and how it can enhance swimming performance. A fin ray is a thin rod made of pieces of bone linked together by collagen fibers. Fish fins are made up of an array of fin rays, and these structures allow fish to perform more complex swimming maneuvers than man-made vehicles. We modelled the fin ray as two elastic beams sandwiching a material of moderate shear modulus.  We then placed the fin ray in an oncoming flow, and studied the best method of moving the fin ray for efficient swimming. We found that the fin ray can lead to improved swimming efficiency compared to a passive fin.

A key component of biological locomotion at moderate and high Reynolds numbers is interactions between vortices and flexible bodies. If the motion of the body is not prescribed, these are challenging computational problems. We developed new computational methods for these body-vortex interactions. The method used higher resolution near the vortex as it approaches the body and apparently collides with it. This required reformulating some of the underlying equations.

We also studied a simpler version of the problem and obtained closed-form solutions.

In collaboration with the Lauder Lab at Harvard, we studied the swimming of robotic foils and found mathematical laws for how the swimming speed depends on the foil's bending rigidity and length. These laws explained the experimental data well. We also simulated the impact of vortices with fish fins, and found that very flexible fins undergo smaller deflections than rigid fins by "going with the flow".

We then studied a series of problems on jellyfish swimming together with Laura Miller at UNC-Chapel Hill. We found swimming motions of jellyfish which are optimal for efficiency. These generally agree with motions found in the biological literature. Vortex shedding is an important phenomenon which is particularly sensitive to the bell motions. In general, the jellyfish should avoid fast accelerations to move efficiently.

In our work on snake locomotion, we studied the crawling of snakes on flat and inclined surfaces. We again determined optimal motions computationally and theoretically, and showed how the commonly-observed undulating motion arises as a mathematical optimum.

The broader impacts included the training of one graduate student and two undergraduates in mathematical biology and applied mathematics. The PI also interacted closely with biologists at Harvard to improve our understanding of fish swimming. Many of our results have been cited by biologists, physicists, and engineers working on robotic foils, jellyfish swimming, and snake locomotion, as well as energy harvesting in fluids. Miller and Alben organized a symposium at the Society of Integrative and Comparative Biology on using experiments and mathematical models to study problems in animal locomotion. This symposium was associated with a workshop on training at the interface of mathematics and biology. The results of the workshop and symposium are published in the journal Integrative and Comparative Biology.
